parts.title: Welcome to 3D Chemistry!
parts.description: Explore molecular structures in three dimensions and understand how atoms bond together to form compounds. Interactive 3D models help visualize molecular geometry and chemical bonding.

parts.content:
üß¨ What are molecules?

Molecules are groups of atoms held together by chemical bonds. The 3D arrangement of these atoms determines the molecule's properties, behavior, and function.

‚ú® Why 3D visualization matters:
‚Ä¢ Understand molecular geometry
‚Ä¢ Visualize bond angles and lengths
‚Ä¢ See how molecules interact
‚Ä¢ Predict chemical behavior

parts.title: Simple Molecules
parts.description: Let's start with basic molecules that form the foundation of chemistry. These simple structures demonstrate fundamental bonding principles.

parts.explanation:
üíß Water (H‚ÇÇO)

Water is essential for life! Notice the bent molecular geometry - the oxygen atom (red) is bonded to two hydrogen atoms (white) at an angle of about 104.5¬∞.

Key features:
‚Ä¢ Polar molecule (uneven charge distribution)
‚Ä¢ Bent shape due to lone electron pairs
‚Ä¢ Forms hydrogen bonds with other water molecules
parts.title: Water Molecule

parts.explanation:
üî• Methane (CH‚ÇÑ)

Methane is the simplest hydrocarbon and main component of natural gas. The carbon atom (gray/black) is at the center with four hydrogen atoms (white) arranged in a tetrahedral geometry.

Key features:
‚Ä¢ Tetrahedral shape (109.5¬∞ bond angles)
‚Ä¢ Non-polar molecule
‚Ä¢ Primary component of natural gas
‚Ä¢ Greenhouse gas
parts.title: Methane - The Simplest Hydrocarbon

parts.explanation:
üß™ Ammonia (NH‚ÇÉ)

Ammonia has a pyramidal shape with nitrogen (blue) at the apex and three hydrogen atoms (white) forming the base. The lone pair of electrons on nitrogen affects the molecular geometry.

Key features:
‚Ä¢ Trigonal pyramidal shape
‚Ä¢ Polar molecule
‚Ä¢ Forms hydrogen bonds
‚Ä¢ Important industrial chemical
parts.title: Ammonia - Pyramidal Geometry

parts.questionText: Which molecule has a bent (angular) shape?

explanation.text: Water (H‚ÇÇO) has a bent shape due to the two lone pairs of electrons on the oxygen atom, which push the hydrogen atoms closer together, creating a bond angle of about 104.5¬∞.

parts.title: Organic Molecules
parts.description: Organic chemistry is the study of carbon-containing compounds. Carbon's ability to form four bonds makes it incredibly versatile for creating complex molecular structures.

parts.explanation:
‚õΩ Ethane (C‚ÇÇH‚ÇÜ)

Ethane consists of two carbon atoms connected by a single bond, with each carbon bonded to three hydrogen atoms. This is a simple example of an alkane.

Key features:
‚Ä¢ Single C-C bond allows rotation
‚Ä¢ Tetrahedral geometry around each carbon
‚Ä¢ Found in natural gas
‚Ä¢ Used in petrochemical industry
parts.title: Ethane - Two Carbon Chain

parts.explanation:
üç∑ Ethanol (C‚ÇÇH‚ÇÖOH)

Ethanol contains a hydroxyl group (-OH) attached to a carbon chain. This functional group makes ethanol polar and able to dissolve in water.

Key features:
‚Ä¢ Alcohol functional group (-OH)
‚Ä¢ Can form hydrogen bonds
‚Ä¢ Miscible with water
‚Ä¢ Found in alcoholic beverages
‚Ä¢ Used as fuel and solvent
parts.title: Ethanol - An Alcohol

parts.explanation:
üçØ Glucose (C‚ÇÜH‚ÇÅ‚ÇÇO‚ÇÜ)

Glucose is a simple sugar and the primary source of energy for living cells. Notice the ring structure formed by carbon and oxygen atoms.

Key features:
‚Ä¢ Ring structure (pyranose form)
‚Ä¢ Multiple hydroxyl groups (-OH)
‚Ä¢ Chair conformation minimizes strain
‚Ä¢ Essential for cellular respiration
‚Ä¢ Building block of starch and cellulose
parts.title: Glucose - Life's Energy Source

parts.explanation:
üåü Benzene (C‚ÇÜH‚ÇÜ)

Benzene is the simplest aromatic compound with a ring of six carbon atoms. The electrons are delocalized around the ring, giving it special stability.

Key features:
‚Ä¢ Aromatic ring structure
‚Ä¢ Delocalized electrons
‚Ä¢ Planar geometry
‚Ä¢ All bond angles are 120¬∞
‚Ä¢ Foundation of aromatic chemistry
parts.title: Benzene - The Aromatic Ring

parts.questionText: Which molecule contains an aromatic ring?

explanation.text: Benzene (C‚ÇÜH‚ÇÜ) contains an aromatic ring - a stable ring structure with delocalized electrons that gives it special chemical properties.

parts.title: Complex Biological Molecules
parts.description: Life depends on large, complex molecules that perform specialized functions. Let's explore some important biomolecules.

parts.explanation:
‚ö° ATP (Adenosine Triphosphate)

ATP is the 'energy currency' of cells. It stores and transfers energy through its phosphate bonds. When ATP releases a phosphate group, energy is released for cellular processes.

Key features:
‚Ä¢ Three phosphate groups store energy
‚Ä¢ Adenine base and ribose sugar
‚Ä¢ High-energy phosphate bonds
‚Ä¢ Universal energy carrier in cells
‚Ä¢ Essential for all life processes
parts.title: ATP - Cellular Energy Currency

parts.explanation:
‚òï Organic Stimulant

This molecule represents a class of organic compounds containing nitrogen. Many such compounds have biological activity and are found in plants as natural stimulants.

Key features:
‚Ä¢ Contains aromatic ring systems
‚Ä¢ Nitrogen atoms affect properties
‚Ä¢ Demonstrates complex organic structure
‚Ä¢ Shows importance of molecular shape
parts.title: Complex Organic Molecule

parts.questionText: What makes ATP such an important molecule for life?

options.text: It stores and transfers energy in cells

explanation.text: ATP (Adenosine Triphosphate) is called the 'energy currency' of cells because it stores energy in its phosphate bonds and can quickly release this energy when needed for cellular processes like muscle contraction, protein synthesis, and active transport.
